name: Deep Brain Stimulation
summary: A neurosurgical procedure that implants electrodes into specific brain regions to modulate abnormal neural activity, used for treatment-resistant movement and psychiatric disorders.
description:
Deep brain stimulation (DBS) involves the stereotactic surgical implantation of electrodes into targeted brain structures, connected via subcutaneous leads to a neurostimulator (implanted pulse generator). The device delivers continuous or programmed electrical pulses to modulate abnormal neural circuit activity.

DBS is FDA-approved for movement disorders such as Parkinson’s disease, essential tremor, and dystonia, and more recently for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Research is ongoing for treatment-resistant depression, Tourette syndrome, and other neuropsychiatric conditions.

Unlike ablative neurosurgery, DBS is adjustable and reversible, allowing fine-tuning of stimulation parameters and the possibility of device removal if necessary.

metadata.session_duration: Surgery: 4–8 hours; follow-up programming visits: 30–60 minutes

clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Risks include surgical complications, infection, device malfunction, and stimulation-related side effects.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: High for approved movement disorders; moderate for OCD; preliminary for depression and other indications.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Extensive for Parkinson’s and essential tremor; growing for psychiatric applications.

items: Parkinson's disease with motor fluctuations or dyskinesias
Severe OCD unresponsive to pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy

sections.text: DBS delivers continuous electrical stimulation to targeted brain nuclei (e.g., subthalamic nucleus, globus pallidus internus, ventral capsule/ventral striatum), modulating pathological neural activity and restoring more normal circuit function.

sections.preparation: Multidisciplinary evaluation; neuroimaging (MRI/CT) for targeting; neuropsychological testing; informed consent.
procedure: Stereotactic implantation of intracranial electrodes under local or general anesthesia.
Connection of electrodes to an implantable pulse generator placed subcutaneously in the chest wall.
Postoperative programming of stimulation parameters over multiple visits.
sections.frequency: Continuous stimulation; follow-up visits every few months for optimization.
sections.duration: Years; device battery replacement or recharging required periodically.

sections.treatment_phase: Surgical implantation followed by stimulation initiation.

immediate: Partial symptom relief upon stimulation initiation

special_considerations: Careful psychiatric screening to minimize adverse mood effects.

ideal_candidates: Patients with medication-refractory movement disorders or OCD
Able to comply with long-term follow-up

facility: Hospital with neurosurgical and neurophysiology capabilities

studies: Weaver FM, et al. Bilateral deep brain stimulation vs best medical therapy for patients with advanced Parkinson disease: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2009;301(1):63–73.
Greenberg BD, et al. Deep brain stimulation of the ventral internal capsule/ventral striatum for OCD: worldwide experience. Mol Psychiatry. 2010;15(1):64–79.
sections.limitations: Requires surgery; potential for hardware complications; not effective for all patients.

sections.total_treatment_cost: $50,000–$100,000 including device and follow-up over initial years
sections.insurance_coverage: Common for FDA-approved indications; variable for psychiatric applications
sections.cost_effectiveness: High for severe, medication-refractory movement disorders

lifestyle_recommendations: Avoid strong magnetic fields near device

sections.adolescents: Generally avoided except in select dystonia cases.
sections.elderly: Higher surgical risk; careful patient selection required.
sections.pregnancy: Device can remain in place; avoid surgery during pregnancy unless urgent.
sections.comorbidities: Evaluate cardiac and respiratory risk for surgery.

items: DBS is adjustable and reversible, offering advantages over ablative procedures.
Requires lifelong follow-up and device management.
Emerging psychiatric applications require further study.

seo.title: Deep Brain Stimulation for Movement and Psychiatric Disorders
seo.description: Deep brain stimulation is a surgical neuromodulation therapy for movement disorders and select psychiatric conditions, offering adjustable and reversible symptom control.
